Committee recommends proctoring system
By MARC DUVOISIN
The joint Student Council-Honor Commission committee has
officially recommended that the
University's present honor system be abolished and a formal
proctoring system instituted.
The committee's detailed proposal was presented to the Student Council Wednesday by Honor Commission Chairwoman
Ann Connor. After making minor
revisions in the document, the
Council voted to put theiproctoring proposal to student referendum within two weeks.
The panel's proposal calls for
mandatory proctoring of exams
in classes containing 25 or more
students and supervision of all introductory courses, unless "the

professor can demonstrate a lack
of need of proctors."
Exams in 300-level courses of
less than 25 students would not
be proctored under the proposal
"unless proctors are requested by
the professor or the students."
The recommendation stipulates a ratio of one proctor for
every 25 students during exams
with "at least two proctors for
every room."
The proposal states that two
proctors "must agree that cheating is occuring at the same time"
in the case of "a student copying
from another student's exam."
All suspected violations would
be turned over to the Dean of
Academic Programs who, after
meeting with the accused stu-

dent, would decide guilt or innocence and set a penalty.
The proposal also calls for an
-academic integrity review
board" composed of four undergraduates appointed by the Student Council Selections Committee and two faculty members appointed by the Dean of Academic Programs.
The board would hear all appeals of the Dean's verdicts and
send those it judged valid to the
Office of the President for a final
decision. The panel, responsible
for "the Maintartance of an atmosphere of academic integrity
at the Uriiersity Would also
conduct peb.46 reviews of testing and .kerifencing procedures
and the proctoring'§ystem.

In presenting the recommendation, Connor said the committee
had based its decision to suggest
proctoring on the results of a survey of 779 undergraduates conducted by the joint panel.
Thirty per cent of those polled
admitted to "some form, of
cheating" while 63 per cent said
they "have seen some form of
Cheating."
"On the basis of this survey,
we propose that the honor system be abolished," Connor told
the Student Council.
Though some SC members expressed concern that the survey
had not been approached seriously by students, the majority of
the. Council considered the assessment an accurate one.

By BOB DANNER
The Biology department has
initiated significant changes in its
undergraduate curriculum, effective next year, including four new
course offerings and changes in
requirements for its majors,
members of the department disclosed earlier this week.
The new courses, which will be
offered next year, include three
300-level. courses, Developmental
Genetics, Ecological Microbiology, and Topics in Developmental Biology, and one introductory
offering, Evolutionary Biology.
Biological Concepts, which has
been taught by Dr. Michael
Edidin for the last two years and
is generally considered the starting point for students majoring in
Biology, has been dropped from
the course list. Edidin will instead teach Evolutionary Concepts, which will form a sevencredit sequence in conjunction
with Principles of Physiology, for
non-majors.
The elimination of Biological
Concepts means that majors will
no longer have an Option in their
core requirements.
Also, majors will be required
to take Cell Biology Lab and Biochemistry Lab. Previously, Biology majors needed to take any
two labs in the discipline to fulfill their requirements.
In addition, changes Were
made in the requirements for advanced programs.
The changes in the requirements for biology majors were
made in an attempt to clarify the
discipline while Still providing an
open program that is flexible to

the needs of the individual students, according to department
members.
Dr. Robert Ballentine, undergraduate advising coordinator for
the department, drafted the revisions after the faculty suggested
an a recent staff meeting a refinement of the requirement and a
removal of their ambiguity for
the new catalogue text..
Ballentine stated, "No change'
was made in the overall point requirement."
Option
"Students will not have an option in regards to core requirements but otherwise the program
is fairly open. I feel that rules are
guidelines to be broken when
suitable. A major should not be.
excessively rigid."
He continued,"next year's juniors will be expected to conform to the new requirements. The
compliance of seniors will be on
a voluntary basis."
Dr. Sigmund Suskind, Dean of
Academic Program, said he sees
these adjustments in the Biology
department as progressive and in
tune with the changing needs of
the student body.
"The changes made an attempt
to strengthen the major. They
strengthen it in terms of the
depth and breadth of coverage
expected from a major. Furthermore, the new introductory
courses are aiding in the development of a well-integrated, modern biology program."
In regard to the future, the department has decided in principle
to offer an Honors in Biology
Program.

Employment situation for Hopkins graduates bleak
By BOB BUCHANAN
Employment opportunities for
both graduating Hopkins seniors
,and summer job applicants are
bleak, according to University
placement officers.
"It's getting very tough to get
a job. I think this will be the
worst year we've seen," stated
Placement Bureau Director
Marilyn Bugg.
Bugg said, however, "Hopkins
students in particular have a real
advantage in seeking employment. Hopkins is the best school
in the state and one of the best in
the country. This makes students
here more competitive."
Engineering and economics
majors should- fare better than
most in their efforts to land jobs
Bugg said. She refuted a statement by the College Placement
Council that economic ills are affecting opportunities for engineering students as well.
"We have no fears for engineering students." Economic majors are also in increasing demand, according to Bugg.
The number of recruiters that
come to Hopkins has dropped
dramatically this year. In addition, those who come have fewer positions available than in past
years.
Improving the tight employment outlook somewhat is a joint
effort by the Placement and
Alumni Relations Offices to engage alumni in assisting undergraduates both in job hunting
and in making career decisions.
"We're taking active steps to
overcome a bad year," Bugg said.
Bugg commented .that "the
whole gamut of Hopkins' sttidents" use her office for the purpose of seeking job placement
and not merely fringe students
who could not obtain admission
to graduate schools. "We get
many students who do well in all
fields and just can't make up
their minds as to what they want
to do. They decide that practical
experience will be useful to find
out what they're interested in."

ment opportunities, Sharon

though many job opportunities
look good, no students have
found summer employment yet."
Baughan said many companies
are eliminating summer employment opportunities altogether.
Black and Decker' 'and the
Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company have taken this
step.
Government internshipg are attractive this summer in both
number and description, Baughan
said. She asserted however, that
competition for these positions is
intense.
Baughan also said that engine-

ering students will fair better_

By TOM CONNOR
In the many times I have walked up
the stairs in the library lobby, I have noticed the bundles of free newsprint lying in
the corners. Such journals as Harry, The
Paper, Performance, and City Dweller
have begged me and countless others to
read them. Quick to label them trash in
the face of the established weeklies I
could be reading instead, I disregarded
them all.
Last semester, I decided to break this
bad habit. I started reading the Port City
News, as:it was the only surviving rag. On
February 13th I picked up the paper for
the last time. It did not appear on 27th as
it was supposed to. (I was distressed for
all my hopes of establishing the Baltimroe
Hedonist byline vanished! Where else

if the bartender of The Clark Street Garage could have column there so could I.)

down to their office on 714 Park Avenue

idea of what 714 would look like or
where it would be. Newspapers tend to be
published in the seedier sides of town:
not only does the warehouse school of
functional architecture best accomodate
their needs, but commanding positions

metropolis rather than in the vulnerable
heart of the city. Witness the New York

Kohler and Mahon to co-captain varsity lacrosse team
By STEPHEN LEVIN
Midfielder Dave Kohler and
goalie Kevin. Mahon will co-captain the Blue Jays' 1975 defending NCAA champion lacrosse
team. Mahon's selection marks the
first time in Hopkins history that
a sophomore has assumed such a
role.
Both stickmen are natives of
the Baltimore area. Kohler
attended Calvert Hall while
Mahon graduated from Loyola.
At Calvert Hall, the junior middie
not only started varsity in his sophomore and junior years but
was selected All-Maryland Scholastic Association both seasons as
well. This is his second time in a
co-captain role. In his senior year
he and Franz Wittelsberger (current Blue Jay ace attackman)
were the Hall's co-captains. However a shoulder separation forced
an abrupt end to Kohler's scholastic stick days. The undefeated
team which he and Wittelsberger
led in their junior years is still unparalleled in the annals of Calvert
Hall lacrosse.
Mahon is starting his second
varsity season of Hopkins lacrosse. He started in goal during
his junior and senior seasons at
Loyola, and, like Kohler, was
also selected All-MSA. During his

years at Loyola, Mahon's high
school team finished second in
the MSA. Though he didn't see
much regular season action last
year, Mahon took over the goaltending in the playoffs and was a
vital cog in the Jays march to the
title.
"The biggest difference and
biggest adjustment necessary
from playing high school lacrosse
to intercollegiate lacrosse at a
major college level like Hopkins,
is in the goal," said Coach Henry
Ciccarone. "The velocity of shots
is much greater in college and
much more difficult to stop. So
it is necessary for goalies to make
that adjustment and it takes a
while. Kevin improved a great
deal during last season and was
able to successfully make the
transition when we needed him
in the playoffs."
Both men agreed on their roles
as far as team leadership goes.
"Neither of us are yelling, rah-rah
type ballplayers," said Mahon
(nicknamed Elf for his
happy-go-lucky nature as well as
his diminutive stature). "We prefer to lead by example."
Kohler echoed those sentiments. "I feel that if I run my
hardest during sprints and really
dedicate myself during practice

then everyone will see that and
follow suit. I think that's the best
way to lead a team. 'We're a
young team and we lost a lot of
excellent ballplayers. But we got
some good freshmen and transfers and we feel that we'll be
competitive with any team we
play this year."
